This course will provide students with an overview of Latin American popular cultural forms. Each class will provide stimulating cultural content with which the students will be expected to engage. We will explore traditions that are regionally shared, as well as nationally specific, focusing on major regions: Southern Cone, Mexico and Central America, and the Caribbean.Visual Culture: Students will be exposed to a broad range of visual cultural movements, some examples: Colonial architecture and religious painting, Modern muralist movements, poster-making, contemporary photography. Music: Students will engage with a diversity of musical genres and dance. Some examples: New Latin American Song, Bolero, Son, Bachata, Cumbia, Salsa, Merengue. Also, we will explore the lyrics of some popular genres and connect these to global popular cultural movements. Film: Students will watch a small selection of approved films that engage with the rich diversity of Latin America, including its indigenous past and present, its Hispanic and Afro descendants, and the intersections with Asian cultures in Latin America. We will discuss a broad range of socially engaged filmmaking practices as well as blockbuster cinema from Latin America. Cuisine: Students will be introduced to elements of the cuisines of various Latin American countries. In particular, we will discuss and share different chiles, comparing them with those used in Sichuan cuisine, and students will learn about the historical and traditional foods, as well as gain practical knowledge of preparation of culturally significant foods. This will rely on experiential learning.

This course is an introduction to Mexican American literature and culture. The course will cover representative literary works from leading Mexican American writers of the 19th, 20th and 21rst centuries in the United States, as well as important cultural representations of the Mexican American people. The reading selections will include corridos (folk narrative poems), poetry, narrative, short plays, and essays.
Literary Prices and Awards in the Cultural Transfer of World Literature
Literary Prices and Awards in the Cultural Transfer of World Literature

Literary prices and awards are one of the instruments in the process of cultural transfer of literature. After an introduction to concepts such as cultural transfer and ‘world literature’, the following questions will be addressed: which players in the literary field affect and direct the creation, dissemination and reception of literary works? How important are literary prices in the cultural transfer process? How important are awards for the consecration of an author? Is it about the money, honor or aesthetics? The students will work in small groups and investigate the status and impact of selected literary awards. The course will be completed with a short written assignment about a literary work from the student’s own culture that should be nominated for a literary prize, translated into other languages and become part of World literature.

Stories are everywhere: in literature (novels of course, but also in the drama, as well as in epic, sagas and other forms of narrative poetry, and even within the confines of the lyric), but also in non-fiction forms, or in other media (film, comics, video games and digital interactive media). We are so familiar with the characteristic features of narrative that we take it for granted that this should be so. But why should this particular mode of discourse be so pervasive? On what basis has it made such a large claim upon our attention, throughout history and across cultures – and often in fictional form at that? This course takes a theoretical look at the nature of story, or narrative, as a way of meaning; it situates the subtle and elaborate manifestations of narrative in literature within a series of much larger contexts, ranging across disciplines and media, tracing the links between these high cultural instances of story and the fundamentals of how we think. We shall be concerned both with how we make sense of narratives, and how we use narrative as a way of making sense.Course structure:？Introduction to (literary) narrative theory (basic concepts and assumptions)？Narrative and Fictionality (ontology, representation, communication and rhetoric)？Narratives across Media (film, comics and interactive media)Narrative Cognition (embodiment, selfhood, temporality, causality and complexity)

Culture Clash: Conquest in Latin America
Culture Clash: Conquest in Latin America

This course will introduce students to multi-cultural complexity of Latin America by focusing on the period of conquest. Students will explore how advanced weaponry, superior military strategy, Indian allies, and biological attacks contributed to the downfall of the Aztec and Inca empires. Students will also study failed efforts at conquest and less violent encounters between Europeans, Native Peoples, and Africans in the Americas. Reflecting back on this period of early contact between diverse people sheds light on the cultural complexity of Latin America today.
